name: Fasta histogram
tagline: Creates a histogram for the read lengths of a FASTA file.
body:
### Welcome to the FASTA Histogram Creator.

### FASTA Files
FASTA files contain genomic information as well as a name for that sequence. The format of the file looks like: 

`>name_of_read`
`NUCLEOTIDE_SEQUENCE`

### Program Requirements
In order to run the Python program draw_histogram.py, you MUST have pylab installed. The program uses Python's pylab tool to create its visualization. You can run this program on the command line, by specifying the required parameter of a FASTA file and optional parameter (num_bins) of the number of bins (default is 10). You can call the program in the command line as follows:

`[user@localhost] $ draw_histogram.py fasta_file.fasta -num_bins 25`

### Output Histogram
This program produces a histogram of the lengths of the reads of the input FASTA. Each FASTA input can contain thousands of reads and it is often difficult to get a good understanding of your read sizes by simply looking at the FASTA. The histogram produced shows the distribution of your read lengths, with size on the x-axis and number of reads in that bin on the y-axis.

### Authors and Contributors
This program was created at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Apprill Lab by Evan Denmark (@edenmark).
